problem:
Let $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ be real numbers such that $a \ge b \ge c \ge 0$ and $a + b = 16.$  Find the maximum value of
\[\sqrt{c(b - c)} + \sqrt{c(a - c)}.\]
solution:
By Cauchy-Schwarz,
\begin{align*}
\left( \sqrt{c(b - c)} + \sqrt{c(a - c)} \right)^2 &\le (1 + 1)(c(b - c) + c(a - c)) \\
&= 2(bc - c^2 + ac - c^2) \\
&= 2((a + b)c - 2c^2) \\
&= 2(16c - 2c^2) \\
&= 4(8c - c^2).
\end{align*}The maximum of $8c - c^2$ occurs at $c = 4,$ for a maximum value of 16, so
\[\sqrt{c(b - c)} + \sqrt{c(a - c)} \le \sqrt{4 \cdot 16} = 8.\]Equality occurs when $a = b = 8$ and $c = 4,$ so the maximum value is $\boxed{8}.$
